Vocabulary.mean: When someone is afraid, they feel fear.

Vocabulary.mean: When you have pride, you are happy with yourself.
Vocabulary.example: I take pride in getting good grades.

Vocabulary.mean: Proof is a fact that shows something is real.
Vocabulary.example: They used his fingerprint as proof for the crime he committed.

Vocabulary.mean: To quit something means to stop doing it.
Vocabulary.example: I quit running because I got tired.

Vocabulary.mean: To spin is to turn around in circles.
Vocabulary.example: The boy kept spinning until he fell down.

Vocabulary.mean: When people or things are tiny, they are very small.
Vocabulary.example: A baby’s hand is tiny.

Vocabulary.mean: A tutor is someone who gives lessons in a certain subject.
Vocabulary.example: My sister is bad at math. So my mother hired a tutor to help her.

Vocabulary.mean: If something is apparent, it is easy to see.
Vocabulary.example: Her happiness was apparent from the smile on her face.

Vocabulary.mean: When people are blind, they cannot see.
Vocabulary.example: The blind man didn’t see the hole and almost fell in.

Vocabulary.mean: To calculate is to find an answer using math.
Vocabulary.example: I calculated how much money I would need to buy the car.

Vocabulary.mean: To chat is to talk with someone.
Vocabulary.example: Even though they were far apart, the couple chatted every day.

Vocabulary.mean: To commit to something is to promise to do it.
Vocabulary.example: Seth wanted to go home, but he had committed to finishing the job.

Vocabulary.mean: To compose something is to make it from smaller parts.
Vocabulary.example: Tonya composed her report using many sources of information.

Vocabulary.mean: A dormitory is a school building where students live.
Vocabulary.example: I will move into the dormitory at the beginning of the school year.

Vocabulary.mean: To exhaust someone is to make them tired.
Vocabulary.example: John exhausted himself by swimming all day.

Vocabulary.mean: A greenhouse is a small glass building that is used to grow plants.
Vocabulary.example: We have a small greenhouse in our backyard where we grow plants.

Vocabulary.mean: To ignore something is to act like you do not see or hear it.
Vocabulary.example: I ignored the message he was making and kept studying.

Vocabulary.mean: If something is obvious, it is clear and easily seen.
Vocabulary.example: It was obvious that he was tired. He kept falling asleep.

Vocabulary.mean: Physics is a science that deals with energy and how it affects things.
Vocabulary.example: In physics class, we used Newton’s Cradle to learn about energy.

Vocabulary.mean: A portion of something is a part of it.
Vocabulary.example: I only ate a small portion of the pizza.

Vocabulary.mean: To remind someone is to tell them to remember to do something.
Vocabulary.example: Nick’s dad reminded him to do his homework.

Vocabulary.mean: A secretary is a person who works in an office.
Vocabulary.example: Rebecca asked her secretary to type a report.

Vocabulary.mean: If something is severe, it is very bad or serious.
Vocabulary.example: After hitting his hand with the hammer, Sam was in severe pain.

Vocabulary.mean: If someone has a talent, they are naturally able to do it well.
Vocabulary.example: Maria has a talent for playing the piano.

Vocabulary.mean: A thesis is an idea that needs to be proved.
Vocabulary.example: She did not support her thesis very well.

Vocabulary.mean: A uniform is a piece of clothing worn by people of the same group.
Vocabulary.example: All the members of our marching band wear matching uniforms.

Vocabulary.mean: Vision is the act of seeing.
Vocabulary.example: The eye doctor tested my vision.

Vocabulary.mean: To absorb a liquid means to take it inside.
Vocabulary.example: He used a sponge to absorb the water on the floor.

Vocabulary.mean: A boss is a person in charge of other people at work.
Vocabulary.example: My boss is a nice person.

Vocabulary.mean: A committee is a group of people who meet together to make decisions.
Vocabulary.example: The school’s committee agreed on a new dress code for students.

Vocabulary.mean: A contract is a written agreement between two people.
Vocabulary.example: The woman signed a contract when she bought the house.

Vocabulary.mean: A crew is a group of workers.
Vocabulary.example: My father has a crew. They help him build houses.

Vocabulary.mean: To devote time to something means to spend a lot of time doing it.
Vocabulary.example: She devotes two hours a day to playing the piano.

Vocabulary.mean: To dig is to make a hole in the ground.
Vocabulary.example: My dog digs in the yard so he can hide his bones.

Vocabulary.mean: To dine means to eat dinner.
Vocabulary.example: The young couple dined at their home.

Vocabulary.mean: To donate is to give something to a charity or organization.
Vocabulary.example: We donate money to Christmas charities every year.

Vocabulary.mean: If something is double, it is twice as much, or twice as many.
Vocabulary.example: I paid almost double the amount for that shirt.

Vocabulary.mean: To elevate something is to put it at a higher level.
Vocabulary.example: The man elevated the picture so he could see it better.

Vocabulary.mean: A flavor is the taste of food or drinks.
Vocabulary.example: The flavor of the ice cream was very good.

Vocabulary.mean: A foundation is a group that provides money for research.
Vocabulary.example: The foundation raised money to give scholarships to students.

Vocabulary.mean: A generation is a group of people who live at the same time.
Vocabulary.example: My grandparents are from a different generation than me.

Vocabulary.mean: A handle is the part of an object people hold while using it.
Vocabulary.example: The pot is very hot. So pick it up by the handle.

Vocabulary.mean: A layer covers over something or is between two things.
Vocabulary.example: There was a layer of snow on the tops of the houses this morning.

Vocabulary.mean: Mud is soft, wet dirt.
Vocabulary.example: My brother played rugby in the mud. Now he’s dirty.

Vocabulary.mean: If something is smooth, it has no bumps.
Vocabulary.example: The baby’s skin felt very smooth.

Vocabulary.mean: Soil is the top layer of land on the Earth.
Vocabulary.example: The boy planted flowers in the soil and watered them every day.

Vocabulary.mean: If people or things are unique, they are not like the others.
Vocabulary.example: Her dog is unique. I’ve never seen one quite like it.

Vocabulary.mean: A chamber is an old word for a bedroom.
Vocabulary.example: The girl was tired. She went to her chamber fora nap.

Vocabulary.mean: To deny something is to say it is not true.
Vocabulary.example: The boy denied that he broke the window.

Vocabulary.mean: A document is an official piece of writing.
Vocabulary.example: He was given an official document proving he was a citizen.

Vocabulary.mean: To emphasize is to give importance or attention to something.
Vocabulary.example: She emphasized the key points by circling them in red ink.

Vocabulary.mean: A fever is a high body temperature that people get when they are sick.
Vocabulary.example: Lydia had a high fever so she didn’t go to school.

Vocabulary.mean: The flu is a type of sickness that makes you feel weak or your body hurt.
Vocabulary.example: Since he had the flu, he felt miserable.

Vocabulary.mean: To freeze is to become very cold.
Vocabulary.example: If you don’t wear your coat in winter, you will freeze.

Vocabulary.mean: A gesture is a movement of the hands or body.
Vocabulary.example: My teacher makes a lot of gestures when she speaks.

Vocabulary.mean: To interrupt is to briefly stop someone when they are doing something.
Vocabulary.example: My mother interrupted me when I was trying to listen to music.

Vocabulary.mean: To last is to continue or go on for an amount of time.
Vocabulary.example: The football match lasted for nearly two hours.

Vocabulary.mean: Likeness means the state of being like, or resemblance.
Vocabulary.example: Michelle bears a strong likeness to her older sister Kate.

Vocabulary.mean: Moreover means besides or in addition to something.
Vocabulary.example: It’s cold outside. Moreover, the wind is very strong.

Vocabulary.mean: A perspective is the way you think about something.
Vocabulary.example: The man’s speech gave me a new perspective on our country.

Vocabulary.mean: When something is rational, it is normal or practical.
Vocabulary.example: It is hard to think in a rational way when you are scared.

Vocabulary.mean: To recover is to go back to normal after something bad happens.
Vocabulary.example: I hope the city will recover soon after the flood.

Vocabulary.mean: To rely on something or someone is to trust or depend on them.
Vocabulary.example: The boy relied on his older brother to help him.

Vocabulary.mean: To shock people is to surprise them.
Vocabulary.example: The man was shocked by the news.

Vocabulary.mean: When people are shy, they are nervous around people strange to them.
Vocabulary.example: The girl was too shy to try out for the play.

Vocabulary.mean: To stare at something is to look at it for a long time.
Vocabulary.example: The young couple stared into each other’s eyes.

Vocabulary.mean: Thus means as a result or for that reason.
Vocabulary.example: The sun was shining. Thus, I wore my sunglasses.

Vocabulary.mean: An aim is a goal someone wants to make happen.
Vocabulary.example: My aim is to become a helicopter pilot.

Vocabulary.mean: To attach is to put two things together.
Vocabulary.example: I attached the socks to the clothesline to dry.

Vocabulary.mean: To bet is to risk money on the result of a game or a business.
Vocabulary.example: How much will you bet that your horse will win?

Vocabulary.mean: A carriage is a vehicle pulled by a horse.
Vocabulary.example: We took a carriage ride in the park.

Vocabulary.mean: If something is classic, it is typical.
Vocabulary.example: The athlete made a classic mistakestarted running too soon.

Vocabulary.mean: To commute is to travel a long distance to get to work.
Vocabulary.example: I usually commute to work on the train.

Vocabulary.mean: To confirm is to make sure something is correct.
Vocabulary.example: Winning the game confirmed that James was a good player.

Vocabulary.mean: To criticize is to say you do not like someone or something.
Vocabulary.example: He criticized his wife forspending too much money.

Vocabulary.mean: To differ is to not be the same as another person or thing.
Vocabulary.example: I differ from my brother: he is short, while I am tall.

Vocabulary.mean: An expense is the money that people spend on something.
Vocabulary.example: She wrote down all the expenses for her trip.

Vocabulary.mean: If something is formal, it is done in an official way.
Vocabulary.example: It was a formal dinner, so we wore our best clothes.

Vocabulary.mean: Height is how tall someone or something is.
Vocabulary.example: My height is 168 centimeters.

Vocabulary.mean: To invent something is to create something that never existed before.
Vocabulary.example: My grandfather has invented some interesting things.

Vocabulary.mean: If someone is junior in their job, they do not have a lot of power.
Vocabulary.example: When she started at the company, she was only a junior manager.

Vocabulary.mean: Labor is the act of doing or making something.
Vocabulary.example: Building the house took a lot of labor.

Vocabulary.mean: A mechanic is someone who fixes vehicles or machines.
Vocabulary.example: We took the car to the mechanic to be fixed.

Vocabulary.mean: If something is prime, it is the most important one.
Vocabulary.example: Dirty air is a prime cause of illness.

Vocabulary.mean: To shift to something is to move into a new place or direction.
Vocabulary.example: He shifted to the other side of the table to eat his breakfast.

Vocabulary.mean: A signal is a sound or action that tells someone to do something.
Vocabulary.example: The coach blew his whistle as a signal to begin the game.

Vocabulary.mean: When people are sincere, they tell the truth.
Vocabulary.example: He sounded sincere when he apologized to me.

Vocabulary.mean: Ability is the quality of a person being able to do something well.
Vocabulary.example: His swimming abilities let him cross the entire lake.

Vocabulary.mean: Agriculture is the growing of food and animals.
Vocabulary.example: The farmer studied agriculture in college.

Vocabulary.mean: A cartoon is a funny drawing.
Vocabulary.example: Sometimes, people draw cartoons for the newspaper.

Vocabulary.mean: The ceiling is the top of a room.
Vocabulary.example: He painted the ceiling with a special roller.

Vocabulary.mean: To convince someone means to make them sure of something.
Vocabulary.example: She convinced me to buy the house.

Vocabulary.mean: When you are curious about something, you want to know more about it,
Vocabulary.example: I opened up the clock because I was curious about how it worked.

Vocabulary.mean: To delay means to wait to do something.
Vocabulary.example: I was delayed at the airport for over two hours.

Vocabulary.mean: A diary is a book in which people write their personal experiences.
Vocabulary.example: I do not let anybody read my diary.

Vocabulary.mean: An element of something is a particular part of it.
Vocabulary.example: Tackling an opponent is Johnny’s favorite element of American football

Vocabulary.mean: When people have faith in something, they believe in it and trust it.
Vocabulary.example: The sick girl had faith in doctors. She knew they would make her better

Vocabulary.mean: Grain is food crops such as wheat, corn, rice or oats.
Vocabulary.example: The farmer planted two fields of grain this year.

Vocabulary.mean: To greet someone means to meet and welcome them.
Vocabulary.example: When my friend came over, I greeted him at the door.

Vocabulary.mean: To investigate means to search for something or learn about it.
Vocabulary.example: The detective went to investigate the crime.

Vocabulary.mean: Joy is a feeling you get when you are really happy.
Vocabulary.example: I love baseball. I feel joy when I play.

Vocabulary.mean: A label is a tag that tells about something.
Vocabulary.example: The label on the back of your shirt will tell you what size it is.

Vocabulary.mean: A monk is a religious person who lives a simple life.
Vocabulary.example: The monks knew a lot about religion.

Vocabulary.mean: When something is odd, it is unusual.
Vocabulary.example: Her cat is odd. It walks on two feet.

Vocabulary.mean: To pause means to stop doing something for a while.
Vocabulary.example: Since she was so hungry, she paused to make a snack.

Vocabulary.mean: A priest is a person trained to perform religious duties.
Vocabulary.example: The priest taught us about God.

Vocabulary.mean: A profession is a person’s job.
Vocabulary.example: He loved sailing, so he chose to work on ships as a profession.

Vocabulary.mean: To adopt someone is to make them as a part of one’s own family.
Vocabulary.example: The girl was adopted by the couple when she was three.

Vocabulary.mean: To beg is to ask for something one really wants.
Vocabulary.example: The man begged for some money.

Vocabulary.mean: If A is beyond B, A is farther away.
Vocabulary.example: John’s house is beyond that lake.

Vocabulary.mean: A costume is a set of clothes people wear for a particular occasion.
Vocabulary.example: The woman wore a mask with her costume.

Vocabulary.mean: To exclaim is to say something loudly, usually due to being excited.
Vocabulary.example: “Look at her dress!” Sara exclaimed.

Vocabulary.mean: To extend is to stretch out or reach.
Vocabulary.example: The boy extended his hand to catch the ball.

Vocabulary.mean: A fool is someone who makes unwise choices.
Vocabulary.example: The girl was a fool for playing too close to the water.

Vocabulary.mean: To forbid is to tell someone they cannot do something.
Vocabulary.example: My father forbids watching TV while we’re eating dinner.

Vocabulary.mean: To illustrate is to show something by drawing a picture.
Vocabulary.example: The executive illustrated the decreasing profits of the company.

Vocabulary.mean: Indeed means truly or really.
Vocabulary.example: The birthday party was indeed fun last night.

Vocabulary.mean: To interpret is to explain what something means.
Vocabulary.example: The woman interpreted what her cowas trying to say.

Vocabulary.mean: If people do something kindly, they do it in a nice way.
Vocabulary.example: The stranger kindly cared for the hurt man.

Vocabulary.mean: A motive is the reason someone does something.
Vocabulary.example: His motive for studying so hard is to get into a good college.

Vocabulary.mean: A nest is a place where a bird lays its eggs.
Vocabulary.example: The bird laid her eggs in the nest that she made.

Vocabulary.mean: The origin of someone or something is where they come from.
Vocabulary.example: The origin of the honey that we eat is from a beehive.

Vocabulary.mean: A reception is a party to welcome a person or celebrate an event.
Vocabulary.example: We all danced and had a good time at the wedding reception.

Vocabulary.mean: To reject is to refuse something because you do not want it.
Vocabulary.example: The girl rejected the broken cup.

Vocabulary.mean: Silence is complete quiet.
Vocabulary.example: The man asked for silence while he worked on the problem.

Vocabulary.mean: A stream is a small river.
Vocabulary.example: The boy caught a fish in the stream.

Vocabulary.mean: Tone is the sound of someone’s voice. It shows how they feel.
Vocabulary.example: My father’s tone told me I had broken the rule.

Vocabulary.mean: To accomplish something means to finish it.
Vocabulary.example: He accomplished his goal of running ten miles.

Vocabulary.mean: To approve of something means you like it or are happy about it.
Vocabulary.example: Her coapproved her new plan.

Vocabulary.mean: Approximate means to be close to an exact amount, number or time.
Vocabulary.example: My approximate height is two meters.

Vocabulary.mean: A barrier is something that is in your way.
Vocabulary.example: The Great Wall was a barrier between China and its enemies.

Vocabulary.mean: To detect something means to notice or find something.
Vocabulary.example: The boy ran to the kitchen when he detected the smell of cookies.

Vocabulary.mean: A duty is something that a person has to do.
Vocabulary.example: It is parents’ duty to take care of their children.

Vocabulary.mean: When something is elementary, it is the first or most simple thing.
Vocabulary.example: Children go to elementary school before high school.

Vocabulary.mean: A failure happens when you do not do something right.
Vocabulary.example: My cooking ended in failure because I burned the food.

Vocabulary.mean: When something is gradual, it happens slowly.
Vocabulary.example: Children learn to read at a gradual pace. They do not learn right away.

Vocabulary.mean: An immigrant is a person who moves to a different country.
Vocabulary.example: My parents were immigrants. They came from Poland.

Vocabulary.mean: To insert something means to put it in something else.
Vocabulary.example: The mailman inserted the letter into the mailbox.

Vocabulary.mean: An instant is a very short amount of time.
Vocabulary.example: A microwave oven cooks food in an instant.

Vocabulary.mean: Poverty is the state of being poor.
Vocabulary.example: Poverty is a problem in many countries around the world.

Vocabulary.mean: To pretend means to make believe something is real.
Vocabulary.example: The boy liked to pretend he was a king.

Vocabulary.mean: A person’s rank is their place in an order of people.
Vocabulary.example: The man got to the rank of captain in the navy.

Vocabulary.mean: Recognition is getting praise from other people.
Vocabulary.example: The hero got recognition for his brave deed.

Vocabulary.mean: To refrigerate something means to make it cold.
Vocabulary.example: Grocery stores refrigerate fruit to make it last long.

Vocabulary.mean: Rent is the money people pay to someone to live in a certain place.
Vocabulary.example: To live in this house, I have to pay rent at the start of each month.

Vocabulary.mean: To retire is to leave a job, usually because of old age.
Vocabulary.example: My father is sixtyyears old. He is about to retire from work.

Vocabulary.mean: The sake of something is the reason for doing it.
Vocabulary.example: The parents worked hard for their children’s sake.
